metadata.title: Ex-Solution Synthesis of Sub-5-nm FeOx Nanoparticles on Mesoporous Hollow N,O-Doped Carbon Nanoshells for Electrocatalytic Oxygen Reduction

sections.text:
KEYWORDS: carbon nanoshell, hollow nanostructures, magnetic nanoparticles, mesoporous materials, iron oxide, oxygen reduction reaction, polydopamine
Heteroatom-doped nanocarbons (X-NCs) are at thefrontier of nanomaterial chemistry, particularly in combination with metal derivatives.1−4 In this context, a very new trend is the combination of two doping atoms within the carbon framework (X,Y-NCs) because this leads to a finetuning of the catalytic behavior.5−8 Dopamine and, more specifically, its biological polymerized form, polydopamine (PDA), have proven to be versatile precursors for the fabrication of nanocarbons bearing both oxygen and nitrogen dopants after controlled graphitization.9 The codoping turned out to be key in defining new state-of-the-art electrocatalysts in the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR), where the fine-tuning of textural, compositional, and structural features determines a high selectivity toward hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) as the reduction product.10−15 The inclusion of a transition metal within the carbon phase can significantly alter the catalytic behavior of the doped carbon material. Iron, one of the most abundant transition metals with an environmentally friendly
impact (i.e., low toxicity), is an ideal candidate for improving the catalytic properties of X-NCs,16−18 as witnessed by the large number of publications on iron/carbon catalytic systems.19−21 The presence of iron is correlated with a fourelectron ORR pathway, relevant in the field of fuel cells. The common consensus on iron-based electrocatalysts for ORR is that the metal is entrapped as a single atom on the doped nanocarbon, stabilized by Fe−N bonding,22 generating FeN4 porphyrinic architectures.23 However, the four-electron mechanism can also be triggered by Fe2O3 or Fe3O4 nanoparticles (NPs), particularly if supported on conductive carbon phases.24−28 In addition, iron species (including iron oxide NPs) supported on carbon are also useful for several other catalytic processes,29−31 particularly when the size of the iron-

based NPs is decreased,32 thus expanding the scope of the iron/carbon nanomaterials’ utility. A general problem with the preparation of iron-based NPs supported on nanocarbon is that their small-size homogeneity and their stability is often made problematic by the tendency of iron to aggregate into larger particles during typical preparative protocols or operation.33
In the present work, we report a new avenue for the synthesis of small FeOx NPs on N,O-doped carbon nanoshells that leads to structurally stable nanocomposites. We exploit magnetic γ-Fe2O3 core NPs first as a template for the formation of N,O-doped carbon nanoshells and then as a source of iron to form very small FeOx NPs on the external surface of the carbon scaffold. In particular, we used an exsolution approach for the deposition of FeOx NPs on the carbon spheres, inspired by the well-known strategy used for perovskites,34 where a suitable thermal treatment triggers the inside-out migration of the inorganic residues to form the small NPs. Hence, this new concept to access supported and naked FeOx NPs circumvents the typical tendency to aggregation of the metal NPs, particularly exacerbated for magnetic iron or iron oxides, during deposition onto supports or thermal treatment.35 To confirm the significance of the spatial positioning of the iron species (inside or outside), we carried out a proof-of-concept investigation by employing the nanomaterials as catalysts in the well-known ORR. We observe that the location of the FeOx NPs determines a drastic change in the product selectivity: the endo-Fe/N,O-carbon nanosphere catalyst leads to H2O2 as the main product (faradaic efficiency as high as 68%), while when FeOx NPs are translated on the outer surface of the shells, the iron contributes to favoring the four-electron reduction to H2O as expected. This work provides new possible avenues for exploiting the concept of the ex-solution approach for the synthesis of metal-modified doped nanocarbons for triggering controlled catalysis, specifically for ORR but also envisioned for other catalytic reactions. While still in its infancy, a complete understanding of the mechanism of the ex-solution dynamics and the key features may inspire the assembly of other nanomaterials bearing a diverse range of metal NPs. We accessed the final catalyst through a multistep synthetic protocol (Scheme 1). Highly colloidally stable, hydrophilic
superparamagnetic nanoparticle clusters (SNCs) of γ-Fe2O3 were used as templates for the layering of PDA nanospheres (Figure 1a), which is finally graphitized via pyrolysis under an argon flow. After pyrolysis, the internal iron is leached with extensive acid washing, leaving moderate doses of iron species inside hollow carbon nanospheres, presumably in the form of iron ions (Figure 1b). The deposition of single iron ions formed inside hollow N-doped carbons by the dissolution of iron oxide core nanorods has recently been reported and supports our hypothesized mechanism.36
At this stage, the iron is still completely internalized within the nanoshells. With increasing pyrolysis temperature to 700
°C, the iron species migrate outward via the ex-solution mechanism and aggregate into NPs on the outer surface of the support, presumably in the form of FeOx species, as indicated by the X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis (vide infra). The materials were characterized at every step of the synthesis by different techniques including thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), XPS, transmission electron microscopy (TEM), and Raman spectroscopy (Figure S1). All of the pyrolysis steps were carefully optimized by monitoring with TEM analysis. PDA-coated SCNs (SCNs@ PDA) were treated at different temperatures in the range 300− 600 °C, and it was found that when annealing at temperatures higher than 600 °C, the inorganic phase acts as a catalyst and induces aggregation of the nanospheres (Figure S2). However, upon prior large removal of the internal inorganic phase through acid washing, the material could be annealed at 700 °C without loss of morphology (Figure 1c). The sizes of the FeOx NPs in the final g-PDA700 sample range within 0.5−2 nm with a narrow particle-size distribution (Figure S3), as observed by high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) analysis (Figures 1d−f), leaving fully hollow spheres. In more detail, the HAADF technique, in a combination with energydispersive X-ray (EDX) elemental analysis (Figure S4), demonstrates that samples SNC@PDA500 (a) and g-PDA500 are formed by hollow carbon nanospheres doped with nitrogen and oxygen with iron NPs inside. We can clearly observe that no iron NPs (a higher contrast in the HAADF images) are outside. This result is also supported by the line profiles obtained in isolated particles observed in these samples (Figure S5). It is clearly observed that the iron signal is detected inside of the carbon spheres. Inspection of the outer surface of the nanospheres does not evidently reveal the presence of iron in the form of single atoms, although this fact cannot be totally ruled out, and a very low amount of iron single atoms coordinated to nitrogen, which did not undergo aggregation, may still be present. In this sense, the use of XPS to distinguish between free Npyridine atoms and Npyridine−Fe is also not viable, given the very small difference in binding energy between the two, as was already reported.19 In comparison with g-PDA700, the sample annealed at 500 °C and subjected to extensive acid washing does not exhibit any outer-metal NPs, thus ruling out Scheme 1. Graphical Sketch of the Synthetic Scheme
DOI: 10.1021/acsanm.9b01511 ACS Appl. Nano Mater. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
B
a possible dissolution/redeposition mechanism of formation (Figure S4). Despite the fact that microscopy studies failed to detect single iron atoms attached as FeN4 units, their presence cannot be totally ruled out, although presumably the content of such species would be too low. X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis (Figure S6) confirmed the presence of iron oxide with spinel structure in the SNC@ PDA500 sample. Two iron oxides exhibit the spinel structure, maghemite (γ-Fe2O3) and magnetite (Fe3O4). Because of a slight atmospheric reduction during annealing in an argon flow, the presence of magnetite is expected. Dissolution of the iron oxide left almost amorphous carbonaceous g-PDA500, while no signal attributable to iron oxides was observed, suggesting that the iron inside is present predominantly as ions following acid dissolution. The g-PDA700 sample exhibits no XRD signal attributable to iron oxides because the content of small iron oxides observed by HAADF-STEM (Figure S7) is too low to be detectable with XRD. It is also worth mentioning that the 700 °C treatment does not cause any significant variation of the graphitization degree of the carbon nanoshell compared with the sample treated at 500 °C. XPS is in agreement with the microscopy results, with no trace of iron signals found in g-PDA500 (Figure S8). EDX mapping of SNC@PDA500 and g-PDA500 confirms the hierarchy of the phases, with raspberry-like γ-Fe2O3 NPs shelled by N,O-doped carbon observed for the sample SNC@ PDA500, while g-PDA500 presents low levels of iron oxide confined exclusively within the carbon shell (Figure S4). The Raman spectrum of SNCs shows the three active Raman modes of maghemite at 370, 510, and 700 cm−1 for A1g, Eg, and 3T2g, respectively. Once the magnetic clusters are coated, the PDA layer hampered the identification of SNC peaks, while two new characteristic peaks of the fresh polymer at 1360 and 1565 cm−1 were clearly visible. Annealing at high temperature causes graphitization of the carbon shell, visible by the appearance of the two characteristic Raman bands (D and G bands; Figure S9). TGA confirmed that, upon acid washing, most of the inorganic phase is removed, leaving ∼5 wt % of the metal derivative (Figure S1), as confirmed by EDX inspection, which reveals the presence of hollow carbon nanospheres doped with nitrogen and oxygen (Figure S4). From XPS analysis, we found that in the sample g-PDA500 no iron is detected, confirming that the metal must be buried within the shell out of the range of the XPS detector; the material annealed at higher temperature (g-PDA700) presents a very clear iron signal (Figure 2a), in accordance with STEM data. Deconvolution of the peaks in the iron binding energy range is consistent with a mixed Fe2+/Fe3+ oxidation state, thus suggesting that the NPs are oxidized (Figure 2d). We therefore hypothesize an ex-solution formation mechanism of the NPs, triggered by thermal treatment. XPS analysis of the nitrogen and oxygen types and the amounts of the three used catalysts (SNC@PDA500, g-PDA500, and g-PDA700) also showed significant differences (Table S1). The relative atomic percentages between oxygen and nitrogen for SNC@PDA500 were 8.3% and 6.8%, respectively, and did not vary significantly for g-PDA500 for the nitrogen atom (6.7%) but increased for the oxygen atom (11.0%). Increasing the pyrolysis temperature to 700 °C resulted in only a slight decrease of the nitrogen content (5.6%) and a more significant drop of the oxygen content (5.4%). For all three samples, the peak relative to the nitrogen atom can be deconvoluted into two main contributions, with binding energies at 400.4 and 398.7 eV,
which correspond to the pyrrolic and pyridinic nitrogen types, respectively, formed upon thermal treatment. In addition, minor peaks attributed to NO and NO2 species (403.23 and 406.54 eV, respectively) are also observed in g-PDA700 (Figure 2b),37 possibly formed following the higher pyrolysis temperature. The O 1s peak can also be deconvoluted into two peaks relative to the C−O and CO types of bonds (Figure 2c). The types of nitrogen and oxygen atoms and their relative ratio contribute decisively to the selectivity of the process, as discussed in a previous work.10 Notably, when pyrolysis was performed at 700 °C on the hollow g-PDA500 sample, a change in the relative content of the different types of doping atoms (nitrogen and oxygen) occurred (Figures 2 and S7). The textural properties of the three investigated materials (SNC@PDA500, g-PDA500, and g-PDA700) were analyzed through N2 physisorption at liquid-nitrogen temperature (see Table 1 and Figure S10). The measured Brunauer−Emmett−
Teller (BET) surface area for SNC@PDA500 was 154 m 2 g−1, while upon significant removal of the γ-Fe2O3 phase, the carbonaceous material presented a considerably higher BET surface area (214 m2 g−1 for g-PDA500) and much higher for the sample subsequently annealed at 700 °C (367 m2 g−1). The N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms for all materials showed a hysteresis loop, characteristic of the presence of mesopores (Figure S10), although the materials also had a significant contribution of the micropores, as calculated from analysis of the t plot, which provides the microporous surface area. Barrett−Joyner−Halenda (BJH) pore-size distributions of the
DOI: 10.1021/acsanm.9b01511 ACS Appl. Nano Mater. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
C
three nanocatalysts reveal that acid treatment enhances the average diameter of the pores, as observed by the shift of the maxima of the pore diameter distribution (Figure S11). The three materials were tested in the electrocatalytic ORR under alkaline conditions (pH = 13) in order to understand the implications in the catalysis of the spatial location of the metal. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) under argon and dioxygen (O2) shows a definite activation of O2 with all catalysts, with comparable onset potentials (Figure 3a,b and Table 2), although the current densities increased in the order SNC@ PDA500 < g-PDA500 < g-PDA700.
It was expected that the material pyrolyzed at higher temperature exhibited enhanced currents in relation to the higher graphitic character and conductivity. Chronoamperometric measurements at two different fixed potentials, 0.6 and 0.5 V, were carried out in order to evaluate the bulk H2O2 accumulation (titrated with KMnO4) and define an order of selectivity in terms of bulk iron. Interestingly, the SNC@ PDA500 catalyst displayed good selectivity at both potentials toward H2O2, superior to that of our previously reported carbon nanohorn-based catalyst.10 Removal of γ-Fe2O3, leading to g-PDA500, results in higher current density, implying a detrimental effect of the metal oxide core in terms of the current. ORR selectivity for g-PDA500 was comparable at 0.6 V (63% H2O2), while it decreased substantially at 0.5 V (28% H2O2). Most remarkably, we observed large enhancement of the current density when g-PDA700 was used as the catalyst,
but a dramatic drop of Fe(H2O2) at 8−9% with both investigated fixed potentials (Figure 3c,d and Table 2). Rotating-disk-electrode (RDE) experiments were performed to provide more insight into the electrocatalytic ORR. Figure S12 (right side) shows the ORR polarization curves recorded at 400 rpm for SNC@PDA500, g- PDA500, and g-PDA700 systems at increasing dissolved O2 percentage from 0 to 100%. Similarly for SNC@PDA500 and g- PDA500, a clear reduction prewave, which increases with increasing dissolved O2 percentage, is observed at ca. 0.5 V, followed by a second reduction wave starting around 0.3 V, according to previous literature.38 The prewave obtained at ca. 0.5 V, corresponding to the potential region where the bulk electrolysis is performed, is also analyzed by varying the electrode rotation rate from 400 to 2400 rpm and could be attributed to one-electron reduction of O2 to O2 •−. Once produced, O2 •− can disproportionate into O2 and HO2 −.38
Nevertheless, for SNC@PDA500 and g-PDA500, it is not possible to calculate the number of involved electrons using the Koutecky−Levich equation because of the comparable current densities at +0.5 V observed at different rotation rates that can be tentatively explained by chemical reactions coupled with electron transfer, as was already reported.38
A different reaction pathway was confirmed for the g-PDA700 electrocatalyst (Figure S13). The calculated numbers of electrons obtained by the Koutecky−Levich equation were 3.4 and 4.0 at 0.5 and 0.6 V, respectively. Both curves show good linearity, thus implying a first-order reaction toward dissolved O2. This is indicative of a prevailing four-electronreduction process, in perfect agreement with the high selectivity toward H2O production obtained in bulk electrolysis. Also, the different behaviors in the RDE experiments underline that the exohedral locations of the FeOx NPs completely change the mechanism. The stability of g-PDA700 was evaluated by running a fixed potential chronoamperometric experiment for 5 h, upon which a 25% decline in the current was observed (Figure S14). While from a performance point of view the materials are not competitive with actual state-of-the-art, the ORR investigation provides solid ground for claiming a large tuning of the catalytic properties of the materials following ex solution. The considerable switch of the selectivity is chiefly attributed to the presence of exohedral FeOx NPs, which alters the catalytic behavior of the N,O-doped nanocarbon, as reported for typical iron/carbon ORR catalysts, which favor a fourelectron-reduction pathway.39 In fact, from the XPS data, the relative ratio of Npyridine and Npyrrole should be effective for a two-electron pathway, as discussed above, calling for the crucial role of iron. The availability of iron particles for diffusion of the O2 molecules, together with the remarkable increase of the total surface area, is also likely to be associated with the higher current density. In conclusion, we reported a new synthetic strategy based on ex-solution dynamics to assemble small FeOx NPs on mesoporous N,O-doped carbon nanospheres. Controlling the metal “inside-out” process triggered by appropriate control of temperature treatment allows for a switch of the catalyst selectivity toward H2O2 or H2O as the main product in electrocatalytic ORR. The synthesis starting from raspberrylike metal oxide NPs also enables the preparation of highsurface-area materials with opportune mesoporosity that is favorable for electrocatalysis. The complete understanding of all of the features related to the detailed mechanism of “inside
DOI: 10.1021/acsanm.9b01511 ACS Appl. Nano Mater. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
D
out” will be unraveled in future studies by a combination of the computational and experimental work. However, the findings presented herein will surely inspire exploitation of this atypical synthetic avenue for the preparation of other metal-modified carbon materials for new catalytic reactions. Possibly, it will trigger investigations aimed at reversibly regulating the metal catalytic site locations, mastering selectivity of the reaction as required. In perspective, enabling a reversible migration of the metal NPs on demand represents an intriguing tool to harness a “self-protecting” mechanism of nanocomposites in those catalytic applications where prolonged exposure of the catalyst surface to the reactive environment causes rapid deactivation.

metadata.abstractText: We report a new synthetic approach for the preparation of small FeOx nanoparticles, formed on the surface of hollow N,O-doped carbon nanoshells through an “inside-out” mechanism. By control of the pyrolysis conditions, iron species can ex-solve from inside N,O-doped carbon nanoshells onto the external carbon surface, where they form stable small FeOx nanoparticles. The location (endoor exohedral) of the iron species is correlated with an observed switch of the product selectivity (from H2O2 to H2O) in the electrocatalytic oxygen reduction reaction.
